messages.content: Hi, DentalBot! I'm Mikhail.
Hi, Mikhail! I'm DentalBot, an AI program by Dentaltown.com here to chat about all things dental. What's on your mind?.
Can you tell me more about the process of finishing, polishing, and forgetting it in dental restorations?

Certainly, Mikhail. The process involves several steps to ensure a high-quality, long-lasting restoration.

1. Contouring: After placing the composite, the facial surface is smoothed and evenly reduced with a coarse disc.
2. Polishing: A polishing cup is used to obtain a high polish, giving the restoration a natural appearance.
3. Comparison: The completed restoration can be compared to the composite restorations done previously on other teeth.
4. Documentation: After the procedure, the dentist documents the case with pre- and post-operative images for future reference.

This process is called 'Finish, Polish, and Forget It' because once the restoration is completed, it requires minimal maintenance and monitoring.

Do you have any specific questions about this process or any other dental topics, Mikhail?

[Tag: Show Your Work: Finish, Polish and Forget It]

messages.content: Hi, DentalBot! I'm Mikhail.
Hi, Mikhail! I'm DentalBot, an AI program by Dentaltown.com here to chat about all things dental. What's on your mind?.
Can you explain Soft-Tissue Contouring?

Sure, Mikhail. Soft-Tissue Contouring is a procedure that we typically schedule during our lunch hour. We use one back-office assistant and offset their lunch. The procedure usually takes 15-20 minutes of doctor time.

When the patient arrives, new photographs are taken to prepare for the appointment and then loaded and displayed at the clinical chair.

We use a compound topical anesthetic. Application involves placing the patient in cheek retractors with slow suction to prevent swallowing of the topical. The numbing gel is administered using a small syringe along the gingival margin, left on for 5 minutes, then suctioned off.

The patient then sits for 5 more minutes. We prepare the laser, and use the Spectralase 980, an ultrapulse diode laser, which requires the patient, assistants, and doctor to all wear protective eyewear.

We then begin the procedure, typically performing the contour from second bicuspid to second bicuspid on the upper arch, starting with a test spot in the posterior, then scalloping the gingival margins.

Contact with the tissue is not necessary; the longer the laser is held active in a location, the more tissue that will be removed. Slow passes accomplish the most. In many cases, it is helpful to debulk the tissue to aid in proper margin creation.

This is done simply by thinning the tissues and papilla. Normally, this procedure is done at the 12 o’clock position. Once the initial pass is complete, it can be helpful to take a photograph for evaluation or to approach the patient from the front to detail the margins of the incisors.

[Tag: Soft-Tissue Contouring]

chat.topic: Impact Your Patients’ Quality of Life––And Yours
chat.tag: Impact Your Patients’ Quality of Life––And Yours

messages.text: What's the deal with Impact Your Patients’ Quality of Life––And Yours?

You can tell when it happens They walk in with more confidence They seem to stand taller, smile more and of course, give you compliments
If there's more you'd like to learn, feel free to ask!
I'm all ears

I’m talking about your patients Maybe not all of them yet, but the number is growing These are the people whose quality of life you’ve impacted
Hope this answers your question, and I'm here for any more!
Share additional insights

You think it’s about dental hygiene, perio, plaque, calculus, brushing and flossing, but it’s not It’s not about bleeding gums and periodontal disease It’s about making a difference in someone’s life Good oral health allows people to eat, smile, talk and feel confident about themselves and live a life free from oral pain Your dual role as the preventive specialist/periodontal therapist in the office plays an essential part in changing the quality of your patients’ lives Remind yourself of that daily
Let me know if you have any other questions!
Let's talk about Impact Your Patients’ Quality of Life––And Yours?

You know you’ve made a difference by the comments you hear from your patients You can measure the plaque scores, bleeding points, and pocket depths, but it’s what your patients say to you that lets you know you’ve made a difference beyond plaque and gingivitis I’ve asked a few hygienists to tell me about their recent successes and how their dental hygiene skills have made a difference in someone’s life I asked Cori Gwilliam if a particular patient came to mind whose quality of live was changed by her education and treatment She didn’t hesitate "Yes," she said
Hope this answers your question, and I'm here for any more!
Could you provide details on Impact Your Patients’ Quality of Life––And Yours?

"Ralph* "  "Ralph has been a patient in our office for several years, Cori continued "He’s undergone perio surgery before, and has lots of exposed roots with 4-5 mm pockets in the interproximals and two remaining deep furcation areas on the maxillary first molars I dreaded seeing him because I never seemed to have enough time to get the plaque and calculus deposits off The furcation areas were the worst as they were always infected, so I definitely wasn’t effective at cleaning out the plaque and Ralph wasn’t either
Let me know if you have any dental questions and I will be glad to help!

messages.content: Hi, DentalBot! I'm Mikhail.
Hi, Mikhail! I'm DentalBot, an AI program by Dentaltown.com here to chat about all things dental. What's on your mind?.
Can you tell me more about how to impact my patients' quality of life?

Hi Mikhail, I’d be happy to help.

Improving your patients' quality of life is about more than just dental hygiene. It's about making a difference in their lives. When patients have good oral health, they can eat, smile, talk, and feel confident. Your role as a preventive specialist and periodontal therapist is essential in this process.

When you see improvements in your patients, you know you've made a difference. It's not just about plaque scores and bleeding points; it's about the positive impact on their lives.

Here's a story from Cori Gwilliam, a hygienist, about a patient named Ralph. Ralph had perio surgery before and had exposed roots, deep pockets, and infected furcation areas. Cori found it challenging to clean the plaque and calculus deposits.

I hope this example helps you understand the impact you can make on your patients' lives. If you have any more questions, feel free to ask!

[Tag: Impact Your Patients’ Quality of Life––And Yours]

messages.text: Any insight regarding Craniofacial Implants and Prosthetics?

Author Bio  Dr Vladimir Frias  received his Doctor of Dental Surgery and Master of Science degrees from Columbia University, where he completed specialty training in prosthodontics, followed by fellowships in maxillofacial prosthetics and surgical implantology Frias, a diplomate of the American Board of Prosthodontics, has been published in multiple scientific journals in the fields of craniofacial and implant reconstruction His current research includes 3D printing for craniofacial cellular frameworks He maintains a private practice in prosthodontics and implant surgery and is the director of maxillofacial prosthetics at the Roswell Park Comprehensive Cancer Center in Buffalo, New York Support these advertisers included in the August 2021 print edition of Dentaltown magazine

messages.content: Hi, DentalBot! I'm Mikhail.
Hi, Mikhail! I'm DentalBot, an AI program by Dentaltown.com here to chat about all things dental. What's on your mind?.
Can you provide some insight into Craniofacial Implants and Prosthetics?

Sure, Mikhail. I'd be happy to share some information about Craniofacial Implants and Prosthetics.

Dr. Vladimir Frias, a diplomate of the American Board of Prosthodontics, has extensive experience in this field. He received his Doctor of Dental Surgery and Master of Science degrees from Columbia University, where he completed specialty training in prosthodontics. Following this, he finished fellowships in maxillofacial prosthetics and surgical implantology.

Dr. Frias has been published in multiple scientific journals in the fields of craniofacial and implant reconstruction. He is currently researching 3D printing for craniofacial cellular frameworks.

He maintains a private practice in prosthodontics and implant surgery and is the director of maxillofacial prosthetics at the Roswell Park Comprehensive Cancer Center in Buffalo, New York.

If you have any more questions about this or any other dental topic, I'm here to help.

[Tag: Craniofacial Implants and Prosthetics]

Is there anything more you can share?

About five years ago, implants were gaining a lot of popularity with the advancements in the field and there was a good push for implants over saving one’s dentition But over the past couple of years, we’ve noticed that trend has flipped and more patients are becoming motivated to save their teeth It seems that people are realizing that implants are not always guaranteed to work, they don’t quite feel like your natural teeth, and the process can be lengthy and expensive
If you need further assistance, I'm here to help.
Could you elaborate further?

We’ve seen a slight uptick in patients attempting re-treatments and apicoectomies, rather than extracting their teeth As a doctor who uses CBCT/3-D imaging, is it accurate to say that some of your cases would have been impossible, or at least immensely challenging, to do with traditional radiographs CBCT has improved our practice immensely It helps us during all phases of treatment, from diagnosis to treating calcified canals and recalls
Need more help? I'm just a message away!
Can you tell me about Office Visit: Dr. Adam Inaba?

For me, it’s proved most beneficial during the diagnosis phase; countless times, conventional radiographs left us unsure of the diagnosis but a CBCT showed clear pathology that would require root canal treatment Conversely, we’ve also had cases where we initially thought root canal treatment was the best treatment option, and the CBCT showed signs that the case had a poor prognosis This has saved some patients time and money In one case, a patient presented with slight biting pain to tooth #14, which had previously received root-canal treatment already Clinical testing and conventional radiographs showed the tooth had a failing root canal with a chronic apical abscess, so the treatment plan was to take a CBCT and plan for a re-treatment
Let me know if you have any dental questions and I will be glad to help!
Please elaborate on Office Visit: Dr. Adam Inaba?

To our surprise, the CBCT showed an obvious fracture and significant bone loss that had been clinically undetectable This news completely changed our treatment plan, from a re-treatment to an extraction with an implant How many of your cases are GP referrals and how many are patients who find you on their own Most of our referrals come from general practitioners, but we do see a lot of returning patients who’d previously been treated by either my grandfather or my uncle A lot of these patients enjoy that they get to see the evolution of endodontics through three generations
If there is anything else I can help with, please let me know.

messages.content: Hi, DentalBot! I'm Mikhail.
Hi, Mikhail! I'm DentalBot, an AI program by Dentaltown.com here to chat about all things dental. What's on your mind?.
Can you tell me more about Dr. Adam Inaba's office visit?

Sure, Mikhail. During Dr. Adam Inaba's office visit, the use of CBCT/3-D imaging was highlighted. This technology has significantly improved their practice in various phases of treatment, from diagnosis to treating calcified canals and recalls.

In one case, a patient presented with slight biting pain to tooth #14, which had previously received root-canal treatment. Clinical testing and conventional radiographs showed the tooth had a failing root canal with a chronic apical abscess. However, the CBCT showed an obvious fracture and significant bone loss that had been clinically undetectable. This discovery changed the treatment plan from a re-treatment to an extraction with an implant.

Dr. Inaba's office receives most of their referrals from general practitioners, but they also see a lot of returning patients who'd previously been treated by either his grandfather or his uncle.

Let me know if you have any questions or if there is any other topic you would like to discuss.

[Tag: Office Visit: Dr. Adam Inaba]

# Show Your Work: Stacking the Odds for Success

The process of Class II restorations can be simplified without sacrificing quality. Here's a step-by-step walkthrough:

1. **Preparation**: The SmartLite Pro curing light is used to cure each molar in 10 seconds.
2. **SDR Flow+ Material**: The SDR Flow+ material is placed in the interproximal boxes for even gap-free adaptation.
3. **TPH Spectra ST Composite**: The TPH Spectra ST composite Shade A2 is placed as the final layer.
4. **Finishing**: Finishing and occlusal interferences are adjusted appropriately using the one-step Enhance Finishing System.
5. **Postoperative X-ray**: The postoperative X-ray shows excellent anatomy and radiopacity of the composite materials.
6. **Sectional Matrix, Retaining Rings, LED Curing Light, and One-Step Finishing System**: This combination ensures a streamlined workflow for the practitioner and long-lasting results for the patient.
7. **Low Film Thickness and Excellent Cavity Adaptation**: The low film thickness of the bonding agent and excellent cavity adaptation of the bulk-fill flowable are used to reduce sensitivity and ensure a gap-free restoration.

Hope this explanation helps! Let me know if you have any more questions or concerns about dental care or the business of dentistry."
}

messages.content: Hi, DentalBot! I'm Mikhail.
Hi, Mikhail! I'm DentalBot, an AI program by Dentaltown.com here to chat about all things dental. What's on your mind?.
Show Your Work: Stacking the Odds for Success. Can you explain this concept?

Hey, Mikhail! I'd be happy to explain this concept.

# Show Your Work: Stacking the Odds for Success

The process of Class II restorations can be simplified without sacrificing quality. Here's a step-by-step walkthrough:

1. **Preparation**: The SmartLite Pro curing light is used to cure each molar in 10 seconds.
2. **SDR Flow+ Material**: The SDR Flow+ material is placed in the interproximal boxes for even gap-free adaptation.
3. **TPH Spectra ST Composite**: The TPH Spectra ST composite Shade A2 is placed as the final layer.
4. **Finishing**: Finishing and occlusal interferences are adjusted appropriately using the one-step Enhance Finishing System.
5. **Postoperative X-ray**: The postoperative X-ray shows excellent anatomy and radiopacity of the composite materials.
6. **Sectional Matrix, Retaining Rings, LED Curing Light, and One-Step Finishing System**: This combination ensures a streamlined workflow for the practitioner and long-lasting results for the patient.
7. **Low Film Thickness and Excellent Cavity Adaptation**: The low film thickness of the bonding agent and excellent cavity adaptation of the bulk-fill flowable are used to reduce sensitivity and ensure a gap-free restoration.

Hope this explanation helps! Let me know if you have any more questions or concerns about dental care or the business of dentistry.

[Tag: New Grad 2023]

chat.topic: A Voice In The Arena: The ‘Not-Enough’ Superpower
chat.tag: A Voice In The Arena: The ‘Not-Enough’ Superpower

messages.text: I'm curious about A Voice In The Arena: The ‘Not-Enough’ Superpower?

by Chad Foster, DDS, MS, editorial director [Editor’s note: For greater context on the theme of this column, check out Dr Chad Foster’s November 2021 column, "Don’t Leave the Parking Brake On," and his July/August 2021 column, "The Wanting Self "] One of the best sports documentaries I’ve ever seen is  The Last Dance, which chronicles Michael Jordan’s NBA career with the Chicago Bulls Growing up a Suns fan, I rooted against Michael Jordan the basketball player, but his personal story through the documentary really connected with me
I'm here to assist with any further dental inquiries.
Please continue

One of the scenes that touched me the most was when Jordan discussed his relationship with his father, James Jordan While Michael Jordan was growing up, his dad would often put him down and belittle him in front of his brothers Jordan didn’t go on a deep introspective dive into the subject, but the rare emotion in his voice when giving brief commentary on his father’s disapproval was telling: "When you’re going through it, it’s traumatic, because … you know, I want that approval, I want that confidence, so my determination got even greater

messages.content: Hi, DentalBot! I'm Mikhail.
Hi, Mikhail! I'm DentalBot, an AI program by Dentaltown.com here to chat about all things dental. What's on your mind?.
How do I use Cerinate Porcelain for a prep case?

To use Cerinate Porcelain for a prep case, you need to follow these steps:

1. Preparation: Prepare the tooth structure for the porcelain by reducing the tooth’s occlusal surface, making sure to maintain the proper anatomy and contacts.

2. Impression: Take a high-quality impression of the prepared tooth using a polyvinyl siloxane (PVS) or addition silicone material.

3. Send to Lab: Send the impression to a dental lab that specializes in Cerinate Porcelain.

4. Fabrication: The lab will fabricate the Cerinate Porcelain crown or veneer based on the impression provided.

5. Cementation: Once the porcelain restoration is returned, you can cement it onto the prepared tooth using a suitable dental cement.

Remember, I'm here to help answer any questions you might have about the process. If you have any concerns or need more clarification, feel free to ask.

[Tag: How to Use Cerinate Porcelain for a Prep Case]

chat.topic: Embrace Progress: Treating Transfer Patients with Respect Earns Rewards

messages.text: What's the story behind Embrace Progress: Treating Transfer Patients with Respect Earns Rewards?

Many years ago, back in the golden age, orthodontists enjoyed a legalized monopoly (Some say we still do ) All you needed was a state-mandated education to get a state-issued license and practice in an area with a relative shortage of providers But, with Smile Direct Club and other disruptors getting in our faces—and, more importantly, our wallets—life is not so simple anymore At one point, we enjoyed the respect of most everyone Our profession was easily in the top 10 earning and regarded vocations in countless polls published in national magazines
Ready to assist with any more dental queries!
Feel free to expand on that

All the parents of children who played sports and danced with mine wanted their kids to become orthodontists (I know it was only because I showed up on time for practice and was rarely called away because of a beeper going off during an event or big game ) How did we get to that vaunted position I'll be the first to admit that one of the first hires an orthodontic practice makes—or if it doesn't, it should be—is in sales and marketing
I'm ready to help with any additional dental inquiries you have.
What's the story behind Embrace Progress: Treating Transfer Patients with Respect Earns Rewards?

Just like a Supreme Court justice (the most celebrated profession when I was in middle school), being recognized as a respected professional requires a certain type of behavior What behavior allowed for a profession or trade to become respected or placed above others Integrity comes to mind—integrity being defined as the quality of being honest and having strong moral principles; moral uprightness Are we practicing like this today Just as I railed against being a product pusher rather than a principled provider in a previous column, certain things come to mind, like second opinions and transfer patients, that can strengthen our position in our communities and in the eyes of our patients Look at orthodontists' websites, including my own, and you'll see that the view of transfer and second-opinion patients has changed
Need more help? I'm just a message away!

messages.content: Hi, DentalBot! I'm Mikhail.
Hi, Mikhail! I'm DentalBot, an AI program by Dentaltown.com here to chat about all things dental. What's on your mind?.
Can you tell me the story behind Embrace Progress: Treating Transfer Patients with Respect Earns Rewards?

Certainly, Mikhail!

In the past, orthodontists had a legalized monopoly and enjoyed a great deal of respect. They were considered one of the top 10 earning and regarded vocations in national magazines.

The profession was so respected that many parents wanted their children to become orthodontists. To maintain this reputation, it was essential to make a good first impression and practice integrity.

Integrity, defined as the quality of being honest and having strong moral principles, was crucial for the profession to remain respected.

However, in recent years, new competitors like Smile Direct Club have emerged, making life more complicated for orthodontists.

To maintain their position in the community and in the eyes of their patients, it is essential to embrace progress and treat transfer patients with respect.

By doing so, orthodontists can strengthen their position in their communities and continue to be recognized as respected professionals.

[Tag: Embrace Progress: Treating Transfer Patients with Respect Earns Rewards]
